questions.answer_description:
The UNDROP DISKS clause of the ALTER DISKGROUP statement cannot be used to restore disks that are being dropped as the result of a DROP DISKGROUP statement, or for disks that are being dropped using the FORCE clause.
Reference:
https://docs.oracle.com/cd/B28359_01/server.111/b31107/asmdiskgrps.htm

choices.A: It cancels pending drops of disks dropped using the DROP DISKGROUP command.
choices.C: It automatically unmounts the disks after successfully undropping them.
choices.B: A disk cannot be undropped as a result of a drop diskgroup.
choices.D: It is not possible to cancel pending drops of disks dropped using the force option.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about the UNDROP clause of the ALTER DISKGROUP statement?

discussion.content:
I think it'2s B,E,F
A no; it's a flex cluster and any node can run an ASM instance
B yes; it's a relocate, though instance in host03 is shut down before startup of instance in host02
C no; to keep ASM instances cardinality instance in host03 must be shut down before starup instance in host02, so connections are failed over to surviving instance in host01
D no; it's a relocate, the operation itself shuts down instance in host03
E yes; it's not a failure, so shut down it's not completed before moving connections to a surviving instance
F yes; for the same reason for C it's not correct

questions.question_text:
Examine the output of the asmcmd and srvct1 commands:
//IMG//

Then you execute this command:
$ srvctl relocate asm currentnode host03 targetnode host02
Which three statements are true regarding the execution of this command based on the output shown?

choices.C: It succeeds and 12c database instances connected to the ASM instance on HOST03 can be reconnected to the ASM instance on HOST02.
choices.F: It succeeds and 12c database instances connected to the ASM instance on HOST03 can be reconnected to the ASM instance on HOST01.
choices.D: It fails because the ASM instance has not been shut down first on HOST03.
choices.A: It fails because an ASM instance is not configured to run on HOST02.
choices.B: It succeeds and starts an ASM instance on HOST02 and shuts down the ASM instance on HOST03.
choices.E: It succeeds and starts an ASM instance on HOST02 but the ASM instance on HOST03 is not shut down until all connected clients disconnected.

choices.D: Standby redo log files are required on the standby site for synchronous redo transport.
choices.E: The privilege SYSREPL has been introduced for ACFS replication.
choices.A: ACFS auditing information is replicated from the primary file system to the standby file system.
choices.B: One site of an ACFS replication configuration can be host both primary and standby file systems.
choices.C: Replication is automatically terminated if the primaries file system has less than 2GB free space.

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about ASM Cloud File System (ACFS) replication?
questions.answer_description:
B: A site can host both primary and standby file systems.
C: If the primary file system has less than 2 GB available free disk space, Oracle ACFS attempts to automatically terminate replication on the primary file system.
D: On the standby system, the remote file server (RFS) receives redo data over the network from the LGWR process and writes the redo data to the standby redo log files.
Reference:
https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/OSTMG/GUID-8522E0B6-BE6E-4BE3-B7C7-5EA2ED4A602C.htm#OSTMG34600 https://docs.oracle.com/cd/B19306_01/server.102/b14239/log_transport.htm#i1280979

discussion.content:
I am thinking that 
A. It resizes VOL1.
B. It fails to resize the filesystem because it must be unmounted before resizing.
C. It fails to resize VOL1 because it must be executed as a user belonging to the SYSASM group.
D. It succeeds but leaves the filesystem unmounted.
E. It resizes the filesystem mounted on /u01/app/grid/acfsmount.

that the correct answer is AE and not AD.

The filesystem was enabled and mounted before the resize operation. And as the operation succeeded, why would it leave it in UNMOUNTED state after the operation.

https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/OSTMG/GUID-79A8333D-4E1C-4788-944D-EC86E4278C00.htm#OSTMG95233

Based on above Oracle Doc the correct answers are A and E.

choices.C: It fails to resize VOL1 because it must be executed as a user belonging to the SYSASM group.
choices.D: It succeeds but leaves the filesystem unmounted.
choices.E: It resizes the filesystem mounted on /u01/app/grid/acfsmount.
choices.B: It fails to resize the filesystem because it must be unmounted before resizing.

questions.question_text:
Examine the output of this command:

ASMCMD> volinfo G ACFS -a -

Diskgroup Name: ACFS -

Volume Name: VOL1 -
Volume Device: /dev/asm/vol1-280

State: ENABLED -

Size (MB): 248 -

Resize Unit (MB): 32 -

Redundancy: MIRROR -

Stripe Columns: 4 -

Stripe Width (K): 128 -

Usage: ACFS -
Mountpath: /u01/app/grid/acfsmount
The ACFS disk group is a normal redundancy disk group with 5 GB of free space.
To increase the size of the ACFS file system, you execute this command as the root user:
$ /sbin/acfsutil size +200M /u01/app/grid/acfsmount
Which two statements are true regarding the outcome of this command?

choices.E: They can be administrator managed for a multitenant database.
choices.C: A server-pool must be created with SRVCTL before creating a policy-managed RAC database that uses that server-pool for a service.
choices.B: Singleton services are not permitted for multitenant databases.
choices.A: They can be policy managed for a multitenant database.
choices.D: Policy-managed services specified for a database allow the creation of a new server pool using DBCA.

questions.answer_description:
C: Cluster Managed Services are no longer managed through DBCA. Instead, use the Cluster Managed Services page in Oracle Enterprise Manager Cloud
Control, if available, or SRVCTL.
E: During installation, if you select a multitenant container database (CDB), and configure pluggable databases (PDBs), then Oracle recommends that you add services to the PDBs after installation.
Incorrect Answers:
D: Cluster Managed Services are no longer managed through DBCA. Instead, use the Cluster Managed Services page in Oracle Enterprise Manager Cloud
Control, if available, or SRVCTL.
References:
https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/RIWIN/dbcacrea.htm#RIWIN1320

discussion.content:
B is not true: https://www.oracle.com/technetwork/database/multitenant/learn-more/pdblivemigration-2301324.pdf
"The following command creates a singleton service svc1 for PDB pdb1 in a server pool pool1 with a container database cdb: srvctl add service d cdb s svc1 pdb pdb1 c singleton g ora.pool1"
A c e i think the correct

Why is this statement
A. They can be policy managed for a multitenant database.
not a true statement. 
Am I wrong to assume that a Policy Managed service can be created by DBCA?
Please explain.

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about the services created when the DBCA is used to create a RAC database?
